awd_titl_txt: Conference: Experimental Combustion: Past, Present, and Future -- International Combustion Institute Summer School (CI-SS) 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is to provide support for students to attend the University of California, Irvine intensive combustion summer school.  As part of this UCI Combustion Institute Summer School (UCI CI-SS), graduate students will be exposed to comprehensive curriculum that includes both professional lectures in classrooms and in laboratory environment. The UCI CI-SS is targeted to follow the best practices for diversity and inclusiveness from the summer school participants and lecturers, particularly selecting well-established experts in the field from traditionally underrepresented minorities as role models. The summer school is designed to provide significant opportunity for participants to interact with their peers within the five-day long residential program. The program consists primarily of eight distinguished professional lectures covering from existing methods to those being developed for future applications. The tentative program will be held from August 20 through 25, 2023. 

The UC Irvine Summer School (UCI CI-SS) offers the opportunity to bridge not only the combustion science from past to present but also extends beyond the known conventional approaches. The UCI CI-SS includes three critical distinguishing features comprising: (1) a detailed introduction to experimental combustion methods to better understand combustion physics, (2) state-of-the art combustion diagnostics through hands on experimentation, and (3) uncertainty quantification and comparison with numerical predictions. A true commitment to access, diversity, equity, and inclusion (ADEI) aspects will be followed throughout the course.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major activities of the University of California Irvine Combustion Institute Summer School (UCI CI-SS) include nine lectures and six experiment sessions. Lectures included five invited distinguished lecturers, an industrial information session, and a final recap session. Experiment sessions are parallel breakouts with 12 different types of stations, including the invited research professionals serving as professor of lab practice in sharing their life experiences in combustion, and also early-career engineers or combustion scientists to demonstrate laboratory experiments. The detailed experiment rotation station plan is also attached next to the final program.

Besides lecturers and experiment sessions, the UCI CI-SS includes three other social activities at the beginning (Monday), middle (Wednesday) and end (Friday) for the participants to interact beyond the regular class/labs. An informal research work-in-progress poster session was initiated on Monday afternoon, the picnic mixer on Wednesday included local combustion research professionals joining in interacting with students as well as throwing feedback on the current combustion-related subjects, and a mini-symposium on Friday for the student teams to present the collected results and conclusion from each experiment. The final program week view is shown in supporting image 1.

On the program student management side, the UCI CI-SS maintained the nominal approach that teams of 3-4 students per experiment station for the best learning and inclusion/attention model. The poster session (supporting image 2) was separated into two sessions that allowed the student participants to be able to actually visit each poster, initiate conversation in combustion research, as well as establish an overall impression of all the summer school participants.

There are a total of 40 student participants. Based on their institutions, 36 are from USA, and the other countries include Canada, Italy, and India. Among the USA, the majority are from California (19 participants), and Alabama has 5, Texas sent 4, and Oregon sent 2. The rest of the states are Massachusetts, Illinois, New Jersey, Ohio, and Georgia with 1 participant from each state. There are 5 female and 34 male while 1 prefers not to say with regard to gender. 19 participants are PhD graduate students, 16 are MS graduate students, 2 are undergraduates with identified advisor, and there are 2 post undergraduate and 1 post PhD as either young career path in industry or seeking for the next steps. The majority are Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering majors. A group photo is shown in supporting image 3.

The post-program student evaluation, there are a total of 30 responses received from the 40 participants, for a response rate of 75% (30/40). There are 90% of participants thought the UCI CI-SS was diverse and inclusive (DEI). 96.7% of participants thought the overall assessment of the UCI CI-SS was excellent and very Good. 96.7% of participants strongly recommended and would recommend the UCI CI-SS experience and learning format to others. 100% of participants voted that the frequency of the UCI CI-SS would be offered every year or every other year. 96.7% of participants would like to attend another UCI type CI-SS with different lecturers/experiments. In terms of learning experiences at the UCI CI-SS, the top aspect and the majority thought Experiments were the most effective, and then Discussions and lecturers.

It is clear that student participants are anxious to engage in experimental combustion research (supporting image 4).  This was the most rewarding and also challenging aspect of the summer school.  With the post-program a-year time frame, we are told that the student participants share what they learned from the laboratory session and bring the skills back into their labs (optics skills and/or fundamental engineering laboratory measurement system) and then further influence their local lab culture among the peer/supervisor.  There are inquiries about whether UCI CI-SS will host again. We would encourage other schools to build in more student hands-on experiences into their programs.  The summer school was a fantastic success from all feedback received, but it was also an enormously demanding endeavor, as it was the first time a summer school of this type was developed.  The student reviews encourage a repeat of the summer school of this kind.  We are gratified to see that the summer school met its goal of diversity and inclusion from the invited research professionals to the student participants.
